member.name: T:System.Data.CommandBehavior
member.summary: Provides a description of the results of the query and its effect on the database.

member.name: F:System.Data.CommandBehavior.Default
member.summary: The query may return multiple result sets. Execution of the query may affect the database state. Default sets no CommandBehavior flags, so calling ExecuteReader(CommandBehavior.Default) is functionally equivalent to calling ExecuteReader().

member.name: F:System.Data.CommandBehavior.SingleResult
member.summary: The query returns a single result set.

member.name: F:System.Data.CommandBehavior.SchemaOnly
member.summary: The query returns column information only. When using SchemaOnly, the .NET Framework Data Provider for SQL Server precedes the statement being executed with SET FMTONLY ON.

member.name: F:System.Data.CommandBehavior.KeyInfo
member.summary: The query returns column and primary key information. When KeyInfo is used for command execution, the provider will append extra columns to the result set for existing primary key and timestamp columns. When using KeyInfo, the .NET Framework Data Provider for SQL Server precedes the statement being executed with SET FMTONLY OFF and SET NO_BROWSETABLE ON. The user should be aware of potential side effects, such as interference with the use of SET FMTONLY ON statements. See SQL Server Books Online for more information.

member.name: F:System.Data.CommandBehavior.SingleRow
member.summary: The query is expected to return a single row of the first result set. Execution of the query may affect the database state. Some .NET Framework data providers may, but are not required to, use this information to optimize the performance of the command. If your SQL statement is expected to return only a single row, specifying SingleRow can also improve application performance. It is possible to specify SingleRow when executing queries that are expected to return multiple result sets. In that case, where both a multi-result set SQL query and single row are specified, the result returned will contain only the first row of the first result set. The other result sets of the query will not be returned.

member.name: F:System.Data.CommandBehavior.SequentialAccess
member.summary: Provides a way for the DataReader to handle rows that contain columns with large binary values. Rather than loading the entire row, SequentialAccess enables the DataReader to load data as a stream. You can then use the GetBytes or GetChars method to specify a byte location to start the read operation, and a limited buffer size for the data being returned. When you specify SequentialAccess, you are required to read from the columns in the order they are returned, although you are not required to read each column. Once you have read past a location in the returned stream of data, data at or before that location can no longer be read from the DataReader.

member.name: F:System.Data.CommandBehavior.CloseConnection
member.summary: When the command is executed, the associated Connection object is closed when the associated DataReader object is closed.

member.name: T:System.Data.CommandType
member.summary: Specifies how a command string is interpreted.

member.name: F:System.Data.CommandType.Text
member.summary: An SQL text command. (Default.)

member.name: F:System.Data.CommandType.StoredProcedure
member.summary: The name of a stored procedure.

member.name: F:System.Data.CommandType.TableDirect
member.summary: The name of a table.

member.name: T:System.Data.ConnectionState
member.summary: Describes the current state of the connection to a data source.

member.name: F:System.Data.ConnectionState.Closed
member.summary: The connection is closed.

member.name: F:System.Data.ConnectionState.Open
member.summary: The connection is open.

member.name: F:System.Data.ConnectionState.Connecting
member.summary: The connection object is connecting to the data source.

member.name: T:System.Data.ConstraintException
member.summary: Represents the exception that is thrown when attempting an action that violates a constraint.

member.name: M:System.Data.ConstraintException.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class. This is the default constructor.

member.name: M:System.Data.ConstraintException.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with the specified string.
member.param: The string to display when the exception is thrown.

member.name: M:System.Data.ConstraintException.#ctor(System.String,System.Exception)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class using the specified string and inner exception.
member.param: The string to display when the exception is thrown.
A reference to an inner exception.

member.name: T:System.Data.DataException
member.summary: Represents the exception that is thrown when errors are generated using ADO.NET components.

member.name: M:System.Data.DataException.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class. This is the default constructor.

member.name: M:System.Data.DataException.#ctor(System.String,System.Exception)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class using the specified string and inner exception.
member.remarks: You can create a new exception that catches an earlier exception. The code that handles the second exception can make use of the additional information from the earlier exception, also called an inner exception, to examine the cause of the initial error.
member.param: The string to display when the exception is thrown.
A reference to an inner exception.

member.name: T:System.Data.DbType
member.summary: Specifies the data type of a field, a property, or a Parameter object of a .NET Framework data provider.
member.remarks: The type of a parameter is specific to the .NET Framework data provider. Specifying the type converts the value of the Parameter to the data provider Type before passing the value to the data source. If the type is not specified, ADO.NET infers the data provider Type of the Parameter from the Value property of the Parameter object. You can also generically specify the type of a Parameter by setting DbType property of a Parameter object. ADO.NET cannot correctly infer the type if a byte array is larger than 8,000 bytes. Explicitly specify the DbType when working with byte arrays larger than 8,000 bytes.

member.name: F:System.Data.DbType.AnsiString
member.summary: A variable-length stream of non-Unicode characters ranging between 1 and 8,000 characters.

member.name: F:System.Data.DbType.Binary
member.summary: A variable-length stream of binary data ranging between 1 and 8,000 bytes.

member.name: F:System.Data.DbType.Byte
member.summary: An 8-bit unsigned integer ranging in value from 0 to 255.

member.name: F:System.Data.DbType.Boolean
member.summary: A simple type representing Boolean values of true or false.

member.name: F:System.Data.DbType.Currency
member.summary: A currency value ranging from -2^63 (or -922,337,203,685,477.5808) to 2^63 -1 (or +922,337,203,685,477.5807) with an accuracy to a ten-thousandth of a currency unit.

member.name: F:System.Data.DbType.Date
member.summary: A type representing a date value.

member.name: F:System.Data.DbType.DateTime
member.summary: A type representing a date and time value.

member.name: F:System.Data.DbType.Decimal
member.summary: A simple type representing values ranging from 1.0 x 10_-28 to approximately 7.9 x 10_28 with 28-29 significant digits.

member.name: F:System.Data.DbType.Double
member.summary: A floating point type representing values ranging from approximately 5.0 x 10_-324 to 1.7 x 10_308 with a precision of 15-16 digits.

member.name: F:System.Data.DbType.Guid
member.summary: A globally unique identifier (or GUID).

member.name: F:System.Data.DbType.Int16
member.summary: An integral type representing signed 16-bit integers with values between -32768 and 32767.

member.name: F:System.Data.DbType.Int32
member.summary: An integral type representing signed 32-bit integers with values between -2147483648 and 2147483647.

member.name: F:System.Data.DbType.Int64
member.summary: An integral type representing signed 64-bit integers with values between -9223372036854775808 and 9223372036854775807.

member.name: F:System.Data.DbType.Object
member.summary: A general type representing any reference or value type not explicitly represented by another DbType value.

member.name: F:System.Data.DbType.SByte
member.summary: An integral type representing signed 8-bit integers with values between -128 and 127.

member.name: F:System.Data.DbType.Single
member.summary: A floating point type representing values ranging from approximately 1.5 x 10^-45 to 3.4 x 10^38 with a precision of 7 digits.

member.name: F:System.Data.DbType.String
member.summary: A type representing Unicode character strings.

member.name: F:System.Data.DbType.Time
member.summary: A type representing a SQL Server DateTime value.

member.name: F:System.Data.DbType.UInt16
member.summary: An integral type representing unsigned 16-bit integers with values between 0 and 65535.

member.name: F:System.Data.DbType.UInt32
member.summary: An integral type representing unsigned 32-bit integers with values between 0 and 4294967295.

member.name: F:System.Data.DbType.UInt64
member.summary: An integral type representing unsigned 64-bit integers with values between 0 and 18446744073709551615.

member.name: F:System.Data.DbType.VarNumeric
member.summary: A variable-length numeric value.

member.name: F:System.Data.DbType.AnsiStringFixedLength
member.summary: A fixed-length stream of non-Unicode characters.

member.name: F:System.Data.DbType.StringFixedLength
member.summary: A fixed-length string of Unicode characters.

member.name: F:System.Data.DbType.Xml
member.summary: A parsed representation of an XML document or fragment.

member.name: F:System.Data.DbType.DateTime2
member.summary: Date and time data. Date value range is from January 1,1 AD through December 31, 9999 AD. Time value range is 00:00:00 through 23:59:59.9999999 with an accuracy of 100 nanoseconds.

member.name: F:System.Data.DbType.DateTimeOffset
member.summary: Date and time data with time zone awareness. Date value range is from January 1,1 AD through December 31, 9999 AD. Time value range is 00:00:00 through 23:59:59.9999999 with an accuracy of 100 nanoseconds. Time zone value range is -14:00 through +14:00.

member.name: T:System.Data.IsolationLevel
member.summary: Specifies the transaction locking behavior for the connection.

member.name: F:System.Data.IsolationLevel.Unspecified
member.summary: A different isolation level than the one specified is being used, but the level cannot be determined.

member.name: F:System.Data.IsolationLevel.Chaos
member.summary: The pending changes from more highly isolated transactions cannot be overwritten.

member.name: F:System.Data.IsolationLevel.ReadUncommitted
member.summary: A dirty read is possible, meaning that no shared locks are issued and no exclusive locks are honored.

member.name: F:System.Data.IsolationLevel.ReadCommitted
member.summary: Shared locks are held while the data is being read to avoid dirty reads, but the data can be changed before the end of the transaction, resulting in non-repeatable reads or phantom data.

member.name: F:System.Data.IsolationLevel.RepeatableRead
member.summary: Locks are placed on all data that is used in a query, preventing other users from updating the data. Prevents non-repeatable reads but phantom rows are still possible.

member.name: F:System.Data.IsolationLevel.Serializable
member.summary: A range lock is placed on the , preventing other users from updating or inserting rows into the dataset until the transaction is complete.

member.name: F:System.Data.IsolationLevel.Snapshot
member.summary: Reduces blocking by storing a version of data that one application can read while another is modifying the same data. Indicates that from one transaction you cannot see changes made in other transactions, even if you requery.

member.name: T:System.Data.ParameterDirection
member.summary: Specifies the type of a parameter within a query relative to the DataSet.

member.name: F:System.Data.ParameterDirection.Input
member.summary: The parameter is an input parameter.

member.name: F:System.Data.ParameterDirection.Output
member.summary: The parameter is an output parameter.

member.name: F:System.Data.ParameterDirection.InputOutput
member.summary: The parameter is capable of both input and output.

member.name: F:System.Data.ParameterDirection.ReturnValue
member.summary: The parameter represents a return value from an operation such as a stored procedure, built-in function, or user-defined function.

member.summary: Any returned parameters or rows are ignored.

member.name: F:System.Data.UpdateRowSource.OutputParameters
member.summary: Output parameters are mapped to the changed row.

member.name: F:System.Data.UpdateRowSource.FirstReturnedRecord
member.summary: The data in the first returned row is mapped to the changed row.

member.name: F:System.Data.UpdateRowSource.Both
member.summary: Both the output parameters and the first returned row are mapped to the changed row.

member.name: M:System.Data.Common.DbCommand.ExecuteNonQueryAsync
member.summary: An asynchronous version of , which executes a SQL statement against a connection object. Invokes with CancellationToken.None.
member.returns: A task representing the asynchronous operation.

member.name: M:System.Data.Common.DbCommand.ExecuteNonQueryAsync(System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: This is the asynchronous version of . Providers should override with an appropriate implementation. The cancellation token may optionally be ignored. The default implementation invokes the synchronous method and returns a completed task, blocking the calling thread. The default implementation will return a cancelled task if passed an already cancelled cancellation token. Exceptions thrown by will be communicated via the returned Task Exception property. Do not invoke other methods and properties of the DbCommand object until the returned Task is complete.
member.param: The token to monitor for cancellation requests.
member.returns: A task representing the asynchronous operation.

member.summary: This is the asynchronous version of . Providers should override with an appropriate implementation. The cancellation token may optionally be ignored. The default implementation invokes the synchronous method and returns a completed task, blocking the calling thread. The default implementation will return a cancelled task if passed an already cancelled cancellation token. Exceptions thrown by ExecuteScalar will be communicated via the returned Task Exception property. Do not invoke other methods and properties of the DbCommand object until the returned Task is complete.

member.name: M:System.Data.Common.DbCommand.ExecuteDbDataReaderAsync(System.Data.CommandBehavior,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Providers should implement this method to provide a non-default implementation for overloads. The default implementation invokes the synchronous method and returns a completed task, blocking the calling thread. The default implementation will return a cancelled task if passed an already cancelled cancellation token. Exceptions thrown by ExecuteReader will be communicated via the returned Task Exception property. This method accepts a cancellation token that can be used to request the operation to be cancelled early. Implementations may ignore this request.
member.param: Options for statement execution and data retrieval.
The token to monitor for cancellation requests.
member.returns: A task representing the asynchronous operation.

member.name: M:System.Data.Common.DbConnection.Open
member.summary: Opens a database connection with the settings specified by the .

member.name: M:System.Data.Common.DbConnection.OpenAsync
member.summary: An asynchronous version of , which opens a database connection with the settings specified by the . This method invokes with CancellationToken.None.
member.returns: A task representing the asynchronous operation.
member.remarks: After calling , must return until the returned Task is completed. Then, if the connection was successful, must return . If the connection fails, must return . A call to will attempt to cancel or close the corresponding call.

member.name: M:System.Data.Common.DbConnection.OpenAsync(System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: This is the asynchronous version of . Providers should override with an appropriate implementation. The cancellation token can optionally be honored. The default implementation invokes the synchronous call and returns a completed task. The default implementation will return a cancelled task if passed an already cancelled cancellationToken. Exceptions thrown by will be communicated via the returned Task Exception property. Do not invoke other methods and properties of the DbConnection object until the returned Task is complete.
member.param: The cancellation token.
member.returns: A task representing the asynchronous operation.
member.remarks: After calling , must return until the returned Task is completed. Then, if the connection was successful, must return . If the connection fails, must return . A call to will attempt to cancel or close the corresponding call.

member.name: M:System.Data.Common.DbDataReader.NextResultAsync
member.summary: An asynchronous version of , which advances the reader to the next result when reading the results of a batch of statements. Invokes with CancellationToken.None.
member.returns: A task representing the asynchronous operation.

member.name: M:System.Data.Common.DbDataReader.NextResultAsync(System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: This is the asynchronous version of . Providers should override with an appropriate implementation. Other methods and properties of the DbDataReader object should not be invoked while the returned Task is not yet completed.
member.remarks: The default implementation invokes the synchronous method and returns a completed task, blocking the calling thread. The default implementation will return a cancelled task if passed an already cancelled CancellationToken. Exceptions thrown by will be communicated via the returned Task Exception property.
member.param: The token to monitor for cancellation requests.
member.returns: A task representing the asynchronous operation.

member.name: M:System.Data.Common.DbDataReader.Read
member.summary: Advances the reader to the next record in a result set.
member.remarks: The default position of a data reader is before the first record. Therefore, you must call Read to begin accessing data.
member.returns: true if there are more rows; otherwise false.

member.name: M:System.Data.Common.DbDataReader.ReadAsync
member.summary: An asynchronous version of , which advances the reader to the next record in a result set. This method invokes with CancellationToken.None.
member.returns: true if there are more rows; otherwise false.

member.name: M:System.Data.Common.DbDataReader.ReadAsync(System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: This is the asynchronous version of . Providers should override with an appropriate implementation. Other methods and properties of the DbDataReader object should not be invoked while the returned Task is not yet completed.
member.remarks: The default implementation invokes the synchronous method and returns a completed task, blocking the calling thread. The default implementation will return a cancelled task if passed an already cancelled CancellationToken. Exceptions thrown by will be communicated via the returned Task Exception property.
member.param: The token to monitor for cancellation requests.
member.returns: true if there are more rows; otherwise false.

member.summary: Gets or sets the DbType of the parameter.
member.value: One of the values. The default is .

member.name: P:System.Data.Common.DbParameter.Direction
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the parameter is input-only, output-only, bidirectional, or a stored procedure return value parameter.
member.value: One of the values. The default is .
member.remarks: If the Direction is , and execution of the associated does not return a value, the will contain a null value. , , and parameters returned by calling cannot be accessed until you call or on the .

member.name: P:System.Data.Common.DbParameter.IsNullable
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the parameter accepts null values.
member.value: true if null values are accepted; otherwise false. The default is false.
member.remarks: Null values are handled using the class.

member.name: P:System.Data.Common.DbParameter.ParameterName
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the .
member.value: The name of the . The default is an empty string ("").

member.name: P:System.Data.Common.DbParameter.Precision
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of digits used to represent the property.
member.value: The maximum number of digits used to represent the property.

member.name: P:System.Data.Common.DbParameter.Scale
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of decimal places to which is resolved.
member.value: The number of decimal places to which is resolved.

member.name: P:System.Data.Common.DbParameter.Size
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum size, in bytes, of the data within the column.
member.value: The maximum size, in bytes, of the data within the column. The default value is inferred from the parameter value.
member.remarks: The Size property is used for binary and string types. For nonstring data types and ANSI string data, the Size property refers to the number of bytes. For Unicode string data, Size refers to the number of characters. The count for strings does not include the terminating character. For variable-length data types, Size describes the maximum amount of data to transmit to the server. For example, for a Unicode string value, Size could be used to limit the amount of data sent to the server to the first one hundred characters. For bidirectional and output parameters, and return values, you must set the value of Size. This is not required for input parameters, and if not explicitly set, the value is inferred from the actual size of the specified parameter when a parameterized statement is executed. The DbType and Size properties of a parameter can be inferred by setting Value. Therefore, you are not required to specify them. However, they are not exposed in DbParameter property settings. For example, if the size of the parameter has been inferred, Size does not contain inferred value after statement execution. For fixed length data types, the value of Size is ignored. It can be retrieved for informational purposes, and returns the maximum amount of bytes the provider uses when transmitting the value of the parameter to the server. If the size of the value supplied for a DbParameter exceeds the specified Size, the Value of the DbParameter will contain the specified value, truncated to Size of the DbParameter. For parameters of type , the value of Size is length in Unicode characters. For parameters of type , Size is ignored.

member.name: P:System.Data.Common.DbParameter.SourceColumn
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the source column mapped to the DataSet and used for loading or returning the .
member.value: The name of the source column mapped to the DataSet. The default is an empty string.

member.name: P:System.Data.Common.DbParameter.SourceColumnNullMapping
member.summary: Sets or gets a value which indicates whether the source column is nullable. This allows to correctly generate update statements for nullable columns.
member.value: trueif the source column is nullable; false if it is not.

member.name: P:System.Data.Common.DbParameter.Value
member.summary: Gets or sets the value of the parameter.
member.value: An that is the value of the parameter. The default value is null.
member.remarks: For input parameters, the value is bound to the that is sent to the server. For output and return value parameters, the value is set on completion of the and after the is closed. When you send a null parameter value to the server, you must specify , not null. The null value in the system is an empty object that has no value. is used to represent null values. If the application specifies the database type, the bound value is converted to that type when the provider sends the data to the server. The provider tries to convert any type of value if it supports the interface. Conversion errors may result if the specified type is not compatible with the value. The property can be inferred by setting the Value.
